questions.question: A 50-year-old man presents with severe abdominal pain, confusion, and difficulty walking. Examination reveals moderate pallor, blue-black lines on his gums (shown in the image below), and bilateral foot drop. Which heavy metal poisoning is most likely responsible for his symptoms?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Lead Explanation: The patient's clinical presentation, along with the image depicting Burtonian lines (blue-black lines on the gums), strongly suggests chronic lead poisoning. Heavy metal Source of exposure Clinical features Lead (Option C) Non-industrial Gasoline from automobile exhaust. Contaminated water from lead pipes. Lead paints in old homes. Industrial Battery and cosmetic manufacturing Printing paint and dye factories Glass manufacturing Shipbuilding Organic lead Wrist and/or foot drop. Insomnia. Headache. Mental confusion. Inorganic lead Anemia. Burton’s line - blue lines on gums. Colic, abdominal pain with diarrhea/constipation. Arsenic (Option A) Pesticide Contaminated water Copper and lead smelting Wood preservatives Acute poisoning Gastroenteritis (Rice watery diarrhea) (differential diagnosis- cholera) Hypotension

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the objective of ergonomics?

options.A: Achieving optimal human performance and well-being through work adjustments.
options.B: Enhancing job satisfaction by adjusting tasks to fit human capabilities.
options.C: Ensuring workers perform efficiently without health risks.
options.D: Assessing job tasks to prevent health hazards.

questions.explanation: adjustments. Correct Answer: A) Achieving optimal human performance and well-being through work adjustments. Explanation: Ergonomics: Definition: The term "ergonomics" is derived from the Greek words ergon (meaning work) and nomos (meaning law), emphasizing the fitting of work to the worker. Scope of Training: Training in ergonomics includes designing machines, tools, equipment, manufacturing processes, workplace layout, work methods, and environments to enhance efficiency for workers and machines. Objective: The objective of ergonomics is to achieve the best mutual adjustment between humans and their work, improving human efficiency and well-being. Contribution: The application of ergonomics has significantly reduced industrial accidents and improved workers' overall health and efficiency. Enhancing job satisfaction by adjusting tasks to fit human capabilities (Option B): Incorrect – While job satisfaction may improve, this is a secondary benefit, not the primary objective. Ensuring workers perform efficiently without health risks (Option C): Incorrect – This is part of the goal, but doesn’t fully capture the broader aim of well-being and holistic performance. Assessing job tasks to prevent health hazards (Option D): Incorrect – This is a component of ergonomics (task assessment), not its main objective. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Pg 930

questions.question: Where is the National Institute of Occupational Health(Apex) of India located?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Ahmedabad Explanation: List of research institutes and organisations active in the field of occupational health in India: Occupational Health Research Institute: Ahmedabad Central Mining and Research Station: Dhanbad Industrial Toxicology Research Centre: Lucknow National Environmental Engineering Research Institute: Nagpur All India Institute of Hygiene and Public Health: Kolkata Indian Institute of Technology: Kanpur Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Pg 946

questions.question: How frequently are periodic medical examinations typically conducted for employees in dichromate industries?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Daily Explanation: Periodic medical examinations for employees in dichromate industries are typically conducted daily. Periodical medical examinations: Periodicity Examples Annual (Once a year) General industries Office environments Biannual (Once in six months) Asbestos handling Pharmaceutical production Quarterly Construction Mining Monthly Chemical manufacturing Heavy metal industries(Lead) Radium and Ionsing radiation Dye industries Daily Dichromate Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Pg 940

questions.question: Which of the following is a primary objective of a pre-placement medical examination?

options.A: To evaluate the effectiveness of the company's health and safety programs.
options.B: To ensure the employee's ongoing health and fitness after being hired.
options.C: To determine if the candidate is medically fit for the job they are being considered for.
options.D: To provide health benefits and insurance options to the new employee.

questions.explanation: considered for. Correct Answer: C) To determine if the candidate is medically fit for the job they are being considered for. Explanation: The primary objective of a pre-placement medical examination is to assess whether a job candidate is physically and mentally capable of performing the specific duties of the job they are being considered for. Criteria Pre-Placement Examination Post-Placement Examination Timing Before hiring/starting the job. After the employee has started the job. Purpose To determine if the candidate is medically fit for the job. To monitor the ongoing health and safety of employees. Focus Assess fitness for specific job tasks. Detect work-related health issues and ensure continued fitness. Outcome Decision on hiring based on medical fitness Implement interventions if health issues are detected. Frequency Once, before the job offer. Periodically or as required during employment. Legal Requirement Often mandated by regulations for certain jobs It may be required by occupational health and safety regulations Examples of Usage High-risk jobs (e.g., heavy machinery operators, pilots) Jobs with ongoing exposure to hazards (e.g., chemical exposure) Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Pg 939

questions.question: What does the sickness absenteeism rate measure?

options.A: The number of employees absent from work due to sickness.
options.B: The percentage of working hours lost due to employee absences caused by illness..
options.C: The average duration of sickness absences per employee per month.
options.D: The economic impact of sickness absences on the organisation

questions.explanation: illness.. Correct Answer: B) The percentage of working hours lost due to employee absences caused by illness. Explanation: Sickness Absenteeism refers to the situation where employees are absent from work due to illness or health-related issues. It's a key metric for assessing workforce health and productivity as it measures the frequency and duration of unplanned absences resulting from sickness within a workforce. Thus, it is a sensitive indicator of occupational health employees. Causes: Economic causes: Studies have shown that if an employee is entitled to sick leave with pay, he tends to avail of this privilege by reporting sick. Social causes: Family obligations like weddings, festivals, etc. Medical causes: About 10% of the days lost were found to be due to occupational accidents. Non-occupational disorders: Nutritional disorders, alcoholism and drug addiction. High sickness absenteeism rates indicate low occupational health and can significantly affect an organization's operations and costs. Number of days lost due to sickness: Total days that employees were absent due to sickness during a specific period. Total number of available workdays: The maximum potential workdays during the same period, typically excluding weekends, holidays, and planned leaves Prevention: Good factory management and practices Adequate pre-placement examination Good human relations Application of ergonomics Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Page 937

questions.question: A 32-year-old man presents with intermittent episodes of pale and white fingers followed by a dusky red colour, leading to a diagnosis of Raynaud's phenomenon. Considering his symptoms, what is his most likely occupation?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Construction workers Explanation: White finger syndrome/hand-arm vibration syndrome (HAVS) can be an occupational health problem in construction workers with heavy vibrating machinery. Secondary Raynaud's phenomenon presents with intermittent colour changes in the fingers or toes, accompanied by discomfort and tingling, often triggered by cold or stress. The typical sequence involves the affected area turning white (due to reduced blood flow), then blue (from lack of oxygen), and finally red (as circulation returns). It is associated with: Use of vibrating heavy machinery (in construction workers). Exposure to cold temperatures. Exposure to polyvinyl chloride (PVC). Work involving ammunition. Use of non-selective beta-blockers, cyclosporine, and interferon. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page 931 Raynaud Disease - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf RAYNAUD'S PHENOMENON IN WORKERS WITH VIBRATORY TOOLS File:Raynaud phenomenon.jpg - Wikimedia Commons

questions.question: A 65-year-old male comes to the OPD due to hematuria. Cystoscopy reveals bladder cancer. Past occupational exposure to which of the following chemicals is associated with this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Benzidine Explanation: Exposure to benzidine is associated with bladder cancer and is commonly seen in the dye, rubber, gas, and electric cable industries. Carcinoma Occupation exposure Lungs Arsenic (Option D) , beryllium, cadmium, Chromium, Asbestosis, Silica, radon, Nickel and aromatic hydrocarbon. Bladder Benzidine (Option B) , Auramine, Beta-naphthylamine, Para amino-diphenyl, Magenta. Liver Vinyl chloride (Option A) , Arsenic. Leukaemia Benzene (Option C) , ethylene oxide. Skin Arsenic (Option D) , ionising radiation, Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons. Scrotum Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page 935-936

questions.question: Which metal oxide fumes are most commonly implicated in causing metal fume fever?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Zinc Explanation: Inhalation of fresh metallic oxide fumes of zinc and magnesium can cause metal fume fever. It is often seen in people working in industries involving metal welding, galvanising steel, and Melting heavy metals. It presents with a flu-like syndrome, such as fever, sweating, chills, dry throat, cough, and breathlessness. Recovery occurs within 24 hours. Reference: Metal Fume Fever - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf Reference: Metal Fume Fever - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf

questions.question: Which of the following tests is the most sensitive test for screening for lead exposure?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Urine aminolevulinate level Explanation: Urine Aminolevulinate level estimation is the most sensitive screening test for lead exposure. Screening and diagnosis of lead poisoning Test Inference Urine coproporphyrin level (Option A) Used as a screening test (>150 mcg is indicative of lead exposure) Urine aminolevulinate (ALA) level (Option B) Most sensitive and specific for screening. Normal urine ALA: 1 to 6 mg/24 hours; in lead poisoning: >70 mg/24 hours. Urine lead level Quantitative indicator of lead exposure and absorption. (Normal: 0.2 to 0.8 mg/L) Blood lead level (Option C) Confirmatory test Normal: < 10 mcg/dl Occupational exposure: 40 mcg/dl Treatment should be started if levels >70 mcg/dl Peripheral blood smear (Option D) Examining basophilic stippling is a sensitive parameter for hematological response to lead levels and treatment of lead poisoning. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Pg 935

questions.question: A 45-year-old radiology technician consults his occupational health physician about his annual radiation exposure, concerned about potential health risks and whether his exposure is within safe limits. What is the maximum annual radiation exposure level a person can tolerate without significant health risks?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) 5 rem Explanation: The International Commission of Radiological Protection (ICRP) has set the maximum permissible level of occupational exposure to ionising radiation at 5 rem per year for the whole body. This limit protects individuals from various health risks associated with ionising radiation exposure. Ionising radiation, such as X-rays and specific radioisotopes like cobalt-60 and phosphorus-32, plays a significant role in medical and industrial applications. Certain tissues, such as bone marrow, exhibit higher sensitivity to ionising radiation. Exposure to the gonads presents unique genetic risks. Hazards from ionising radiation include various health effects such as genetic mutations, birth defects, cancer, leukemia, hair loss, skin ulceration, infertility, and, in severe cases, death. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Pg 931

questions.question: A 4-year-old child presents with irritability, loss of appetite, and developmental delays. The parents mention living in an old house undergoing renovation, with peeling paint and dust. Blood tests confirm elevated lead levels. What is the most common route of lead poisoning in this child?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Ingestion Explanation : Ingestion of lead paint is the most common route of lead poisoning in children, while in adults, it is the inhalation of fumes and dust in industrial settings. (Option A) Skin absorption occurs with organic lead compounds like tetraethyl lead, not with inorganic compounds. (Option B) Industrial Lead Exposure : Lead is the most common toxic metal exposure for industrial workers. Used in over 200 industries including: Storage battery manufacturing, Glass manufacturing, Shipbuilding, Printing and pottery, Rubber industry Non-Occupational Sources : Major environmental source: gasoline exhaust. Additional sources: Drinking water from lead pipes. Chewing lead paint on window sills or toys (especially in children). Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Pg 934

questions.question: A 38-year-old male factory worker at a sugarcane processing plant presents with a dry cough, shortness of breath, and fever. On examination, bilateral inspiratory crackles are noted. Chest X-ray shows diffuse infiltrates, and spirometry indicates a restrictive pattern. What respiratory condition is he likely suffering from?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Bagassosis Explanation: The patient’s clinical presentation and history of working at a sugarcane processing plant suggest Bagassosis, an occupational lung disease caused by inhaling bagasse (sugarcane dust). Causative Agent: Thermoactinomyces sacchari. Clinical Presentation: Symptoms include breathlessness, cough, hemoptysis, slight fever, and acute diffuse bronchiolitis. A chest X-ray may show lung mottling or shadowing and impaired pulmonary function. Preventive Measures: To ensure safety for use, bagasse should maintain a moisture content above 20% and be treated with 2% propionic acid . Byssinosis (Option A) occurs due to the inhalation of cotton fibers and jute in the textile industry. It is characterized by chronic cough, dyspnea (shortness of breath), chest tightness, bronchitis, and emphysema. Farmer’s lung (Option B) It is caused by inhaling mouldy hay or grain dust infested with fungi, specifically thermophilic actinomycetes or Micropolyspora faeni, which thrive when hay moisture exceeds 30%. Symptoms include acute respiratory issues, chronic cough, and fibrosis. X-rays may reveal fine nodular opacities. Bird fancier lung (Option C) occurs due to repetitive exposure to air-borne avian antigens. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page 933 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.go v/pmc/articles/PMC7724370/#:~:text=Bird%20Fancier's%20Lung%20is%20a,common%20causes%20of%20hyper sensitivity%20pneumonitis.

questions.question: A 55-year-old male with over 30 years in the construction industry presents to the clinic with a chronic cough and shortness of breath. His history includes long-term asbestos exposure. Chest X-ray reveals interstitial fibrosis. The patient is concerned about complications from his occupational exposure. What is the most common manifestation in a patient with asbestosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Pleural plaques Explanation: Asbestosis is characterised by diffuse interstitial fibrosis of the lungs due to prolonged exposure to asbestos fibres. The most common manifestation of asbestosis is the development of pleural plaques, which are discrete fibrous or calcified thickened areas on the parietal pleura. These plaques are typically asymptomatic but can be seen in imaging studies like chest X-rays or CT scans. The fibrosis in asbestosis is due to mechanical irritation, and is peri bronchial, diffuse in character and basal in location, (in contrast to silicosis in which the fibrosis is nodular in character and involves the upper part of the lungs). Although asbestosis increases the risk of developing other asbestos-related diseases, such as Mesothelioma (Option B) and lung cancer (Adenocarcinoma) (Option D) , pleural plaques are the most common initial finding. Types of Asbestos: Serpentine (chrysotile) : Composed of hydrated magnesium silicate, it constitutes 90% of global asbestos production. They are generally considered less hazardous than amphibole minerals. Amphibole : Contains minimal magnesium content; includes varieties such as Crocidolite (blue), Amosite (brown), and Anthophyllite (white). Symptoms include dyspnea, finger clubbing, cardiac distress, and cyanosis, with sputum showing "asbestos bodies" and X-rays revealing a ground-glass appearance in lower lung fields. Pleural effusion (Option C) can occur in patients with asbestosis when the adenocarcinoma spreads to the pleura, causing pleural effusion, but it is not the most common manifestation of asbestosis. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page 934 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2840547/

questions.question: A 60-year-old man presents with chronic cough, weight loss, and night sweats. He has worked in the mining industry for over 25 years. On examination, there are crackles in the upper lung fields, and a chest X-ray shows nodular opacities in the upper lobes. Which type of pneumoconiosis is most commonly associated with an increased risk of tuberculosis (TB)?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Silicosis Explanation: The clinical presentation, work history, and lung changes support a diagnosis of silicosis, which increases susceptibility to TB due to impaired lung macrophage function. Chest X-ray findings in silicosis show a snowstorm appearance predominantly in the upper lung fields. Radiologically, silicosis and tuberculosis can present similarly, potentially causing diagnostic challenges. Silicotics (people with silicosis) are prone to pulmonary tuberculosis (TB), leading to a condition known as "silicotuberculosis." Sputum in silicotuberculosis rarely shows tubercle bacilli Post-mortems on silicotuberculosis patients often fail to prove the existence of tuberculosis, instead showing only pure silicosis. Asbestosis (Option A) results from asbestos exposure, leading to diffuse interstitial fibrosis predominantly in the lower lobes. While asbestosis is associated with an increased risk of lung cancer and mesothelioma, it is less strongly linked to tuberculosis compared to silicosis. Berylliosis (Option B) is a granulomatous lung disease caused by exposure to beryllium, often seen in aerospace and nuclear industries. Berylliosis presents with non-caseating granulomas and diffuse interstitial fibrosis but has no strong association with tuberculosis. Coal worker's pneumoconiosis (CWP) (Option C), also known as black lung disease, is caused by inhalation of coal dust. It can lead to progressive massive fibrosis but is not as strongly linked to an increased risk of tuberculosis as silicosis. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page 933

questions.question: A 55-year-old male presents to the outpatient clinic with progressive shortness of breath and a chronic dry cough. He mentions working in shipbuilding for over 30 years. On examination, his lungs have a dull percussion note and fine crackles at the bases. A chest X-ray is performed. Which of the following is the characteristic radiologic change seen in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Ground glass opacity Explanation: The clinical presentation and a history of working in shipbuilding suggest that the patient likely has Asbestosis. The characteristic radiologic change seen in this patient is a ground glass opacity on the chest X-ray. Asbestosis is a chronic lung disease caused by inhaling asbestos fibres. It is often seen in individuals with prolonged occupational exposure, such as those working in shipbuilding, construction, or manufacturing(cement, roof tiling, brake lining, etc.). Asbestos enters the body by inhalation, and fine dust may be deposited in the alveoli. This can lead to pulmonary fibrosis, carcinoma of the bronchus, mesothelioma of the pleura or peritoneum, and cancer of gastrointestinal tract. Chest X-ray findings in different types of pneumoconiosis: X-Ray Changes Types of pneumoconiosis Ground glass opacity Asbestosis Black lung Anthracosis Mottling of lung Bagassosis (Option A) Fine nodular opacity Farmer's lung (Option C) Snowstorm Silicosis (Option B) Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page 934

questions.question: Which of the following factors plays a crucial role in determining the severity of pneumoconiosis in individuals exposed to mineral dust? 1) Fineness of particles 2) Chemical composition 3) Concentration of dust in the air 4) Period of exposure
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) 1,2,3,4 Explanation: Factors influencing pneumoconiosis : Factor Description Chemical Composition Different dust types have varying toxicity levels; silica and asbestos are particularly harmful. Fineness of Particles Finer particles can penetrate deeper into the lungs, causing more severe damage over time. Concentration of Dust in the Air Higher concentrations increase the likelihood and severity of respiratory issues upon inhalation. Period of Exposure Longer exposure durations, especially at high concentrations, increase cumulative lung damage. Health Status of the Person Exposed Pre-existing lung diseases like Asthma, COPD, smokers and immune status affect susceptibility. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page 933

questions.question: Match the following pneumoconiosis conditions with their related industries: Pneumoconiosis Exposure Industry 1. Silicosis a. Textile Manufacturing 2. Asbestosis Anthracosis d. Coal Mining
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) 1-b, 2-c, 3-a, 4-d Explanation: Silicosis: Often occurs in workers exposed to silica dust in industries like mining and quarrying. Asbestosis: Typically found in workers who handle asbestos, prevalent in construction and shipbuilding industries. Byssinosis: Common among workers exposed to cotton, flax, or hemp dust, primarily in the textile manufacturing industry. Anthracosis or Coal Workers' Pneumoconiosis (aka "black lung disease" ): This condition affects workers in coal mining due to inhalation of coal dust. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Pg 933, 934

questions.question: A 55-year-old coal miner with a history of fine dust exposure presents with chronic cough and shortness of breath. A chest X-ray shows extensive lung fibrosis, and he is diagnosed with pneumoconiosis. Which particle size is most dangerous for causing pneumoconiosis by reaching the lower respiratory tract? µ m µ m µ m µ m
questions.explanation: µ m Correct Answer: C) 0.5 - 3 µ m Explanation: Particles ranging from 0.5 to 3 µm are considered the most dangerous in pneumoconiosis because they can penetrate deeply into the lower respiratory tract , reaching the alveoli where they cause significant damage. Pathogenesis: Particle Size Effects on Respiratory Tract 5-10 µ m It gets trapped in the upper respiratory tract. 3-5 µ m Deposits in the mid-respiratory tract. 0.5-3 µ m It enters the alveoli and causes damage. Less than 0.5 µ m Moves deeper due to Brownian motion into smaller airways.

questions.question: A 30-year-old construction worker presents with painful muscle spasms after several hours of heavy sweating in the hot sun. He reports extreme thirst and muscle tightness, but his vital signs are normal. Which heat-related illness is primarily caused by loss of sodium and chloride during heavy physical work in high temperatures?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Heat cramps Explanation: Heat cramps occur when sodium and chloride are lost from the blood during heavy muscular work in high temperatures and humidity. Heat-related illness: Heat Disorder Mechanism Features Treatment Heat Cramps (Option C) Loss of sodium and chlorides due to heavy muscular work. Painful, spasmodic contractions of skeletal muscles. Rehydration and electrolyte replacement; rest and stretching of affected muscles. Heat Stroke (Option A) Failure of heat-regulating mechanism. Very high body temperature (> 110°F or 43.3°C), delirium, convulsions, partial or complete loss of consciousness, dry and hot skin Classical heat stroke occurs in vulnerable populations during heatwaves, while E xertional heat stroke occurs in healthy individuals during intense physical activity in hot conditions. Rapid cooling in an ice water bath until rectal temperature falls below 102°F (38.9°C). Continuous monitoring of rectal temperature. Supportive care for complications. Heat Exhaustion (Option B) Imbalance or inadequate replacement of water and salts lost through perspiration. Normal or moderately elevated body temperature (< 102°F or 38.9°C) Dizziness, weakness, fatigue, circulatory distress, Normalise fluid and electrolyte balance; may require hospitalization in severe cases. Heat Syncope (Option C) Blood pooling in lower limbs due to dilated blood vessels. Pale skin, sudden collapse, no significant rise in body temperature Lay down in the shade with your head slightly down; recovery typically takes 5-10 minutes. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page 875
